Ghost of Honor
Those members of the Honor Commission who are
against the proposed change in the accused-accuser relationship claim that the integrity for the Honor System is maintained only if everyone in the community is
assured the grade he fairly deserves. The prospect of a
confrontation with the accused party at an honor trial
would, they suggest, deter students from reporting
suspected violations, thus reducing the effectiveness of
the System.
The System is conceived, however, as ideally being, presumably on the basis of principle,
self-enforc
ing
not convenience. The student who fails to report a
suspected violation becomes an accessory to the fact and
is thereby also guilty under the System. That its effectiveness might be impaired would be due not to the proposed change, but a general lack of commitiment on the
part of the students.
Furthermore, according to the statistics revealed at
last Sunday's open forum, an average of only twenty
violations are reported each year, half of which result
in convictions. Although students submit half of the reports of suspected violations, only three of the ten on the
average result in convictions, the other seven having been
initiated on the part of the faculty.
This proportion exists, we are told, because a faculty member usually is in a better poiston to judge if a
violation has taken place. In any case, it should he painfully obvious that an average of twenty reported violations _implies there is a minimal committment to the
System as it stands. Even if a few students are deterred
by the prospect of facing the accused, the Honor System
will hardly he dealt a serious blow.
That there is a greater proportion of convictions
this year to the same number of reported violations is
probably one reason why the issue has been raised at
this time, and all the more reason why the change should
be carried out. The Honor Commission must afford the
accused every possible means to clear himself, and a confrontation with the accuser might clarify questions of
fact wich would otherwise he overlooked.
Opponents of the change also argue that when the
accuser faces the accused, there is an implicit moral
judgment on the accuser's part which is not present
under the current procedure. If we accept, however, the
analogy of the Honor System to the American legal system, we see that it is not really the individual who is
the accuser, but the System through the agency of the
Honor Commission, more specifically the Commission
Counsel, who acts as proseutor. The trial panel serves
in the capacity of judge, while the so-called accuser is
actually a witness, though one who has also fulfilled a
constructive duty under the Honor Code to report a
suspected violation.
Inasmuch as the Honor Commission Constitution
currently employs the terms "accused" and "accuser," a
redefinition of this relationship along the lines stated
above should be undertaken, regardless of the outcome
of the confrontation question. It should be noted in
passing that this redefinition was suggested by a nonCommission member at Sunday's forum, and was perhaps the most significant comment made at the meeting,
an indication in itself of the value of such gatherings.
Judging from the positions taken by Commission
members at the forum, the Commission seems to be
evenly divided over the proposed change. The issue
should ultimately be resolved by a student referendum,
although we hope that the Commission will first make
further efforts to appraise students of the nature and
implications of the proposal in question.

By GERALD BRECHER
The recent controversy over
the C.I.A.'s funding of various
student organizations in this
country is one of the more ridiculous affairs of recent history.
To read such eminent authorities
as the editorial page of the New
York Times, one would imagine
that some diabolical plot had
been hatched by a crew of evil
spies—dressed all in glistening
black, no doubt—and that this
plot would soon have swallowed
up every student in the country
had not Ramparts magazine—of
all people—not exposed this sordid affair.
This sounds like patent nonsense, and probably is. One of
the things that the New York
Times and other journalistic organs don't seem to realize is
that things like the National Student Association aren't terribly
important at all. The influence
of the organized student in this
country doesn't amount to a hill
of beans. The good gray image
of the independent young student, off to seek truth and enlightenment in a democratic
world is a mere illusion in the
United States. The C.I.A. wasn't
perverting anything that was
simon-pure in the first place;
rather it was taking advantage
of a situation long in existence.

make it through the universities
are—almost by definition, the
future leaders of the country.
Their organizations, then, are
important—not only to the students themselves, but necessarily to their countries as well. The
student organizations in the
merging nations are perhaps the
most vocal, if not effective forces
in expressing whatever political
opinion happens to be popular
at the time.

To The Editors:
Of the 1700 students who registered for the second term, only
415 returned the questionnaire
that we distributed during the
registration period.
289 of those who responded
said they were able to enroll in
their first choice courses; 50
were caught in schedule conflicts; 42 were dissatisfied with
matters unrelated to the schedule, such as advising, course sequences or limited enrollments;
and 34 replies could not be used
because of insufficient or incorrect information.
I wish to thank all those who
took the trouble to fill out the
questionnaire.
Comments concerning course
offerings and advising will be
referred to the dean's office;
matters dealing directly with the
schedule are receiving attention
in my office.
Irene M. Davis
Registrar

The Air Force doesn't want
to waste your college education
any more than you do.
Are you afraid of becoming part
of the woodwork on a job? Your
career stunted by boredom? Few
promotions in sight?
You didn't go to college for that.
And it needn't happen, either.
Because you can pick the United
States Air Force as your employer.
Career opportunities are so vast...
you'll get a better chance to specialize where you want...in the
forefront of modern science and
,technology.

Suppose, just for example, you
wanted to be involved in Electronics. This area alone includes
Communications-Electronics, Missile Electronics, Avionics, and
others. And these, in turn, involve
administrative, research, and other
technical aspects.
That's just a tiny part of the
whole Air Force picture. Just
one brilliant opportunity area
among many.

You'll enjoy good pay, promotions, chance to travel, active social
life, fine retirement benefits. And
yoU'll be serving your country, too.
Or maybe you want to fly? That's
great. The Air Force is certainly the
place to do it.
As a college graduate you want
something extra out of life—to aim
at an exciting goal. So send in
this coupon.
Make sure you don't get stuck
where nothing much is happening.

Jan Knippers of Lawrenceburg. Tennessee. a graduate of the Univers
ity of Tennessee. and a
former Peace Corps Volunteer, first pursued graduate studies in Interna
tional Relations and returned a second semester as a teaching assistant in Spanish on the world
-circling campus.
Students live and attend regular classes aboard the s.s. RYN DAM,
owned by the ECL Shipping
Co. of Bremen for which the Holland-America Line acts as general passeng
er agent. In-port activities arc arranged to supplement courses taught aboard ship.
As you read this, the spring semester voyage of discovery is carryin
g 450 undergraduate and
graduate students through the Panama Canal to call at ports in
Venezuela. Brazil. Argentina. Nigeria,
Senegal, Morocco, Spain, Portugal, The Netherlands, Denmark
and Great Britain, returning to New
York May 25.
Next fall World Campus Afloat-Chapman College will take
another 500 students around the
world from New York to Los Angeles and in the spring, a
new student body will journey from
Los Angeles to ports on both west and east coasts of South
.America, in western and northern
Europe and as far east as Leningrad before returning to New
York.

Quint Completes Year
On Impressive Note

Swartz, Two Frosh
Wrestle In Tourneys

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Displaying flashes of a form,
sadly lacking for much of this
season, the varsity basketball
team, closed a generally disappointing '66-67 campaign with
two impressive wins, thus barely equaling last year's final record.
In destroying Loyola's MasonDixon title hopes for the second straight year and dealing a
94-83 setback to Western Maryland, the cagers fiinished on a
happy note and to some extent
atoned for earlier misfortunes,
but, when compared to pre-season expectations, this year's results—an 8-9 'overall mark, with
a third place, 7-5 log in the Southern Division of the Middle Atlantic Conference and a 3-4 Mason-Dixon mark—will not so easily be explained away.
Though somewhat more accurate (10-7 and about third
place in the M.A.C.) in his assesment of the team's hopes than
pre-season prognosticators like
this writer (13-4 and no worse
than second), varsity coach Henry Ciccarone was hardly overjoyed about the efforts of his
charges, but could not relate
their failures to any specific factor.
Intangibles
"Probably the biggest causes of
our problems were a lot in intangibles," he opined; "I think
the team learned a few things
this year—mostly important that
a winning season just won't happen. Our opponents took us a lot
more seriously, and sometimes
we didn't have the 'little extra'
that was there the year before.
Finally, in thinking of the three
games lost in overtime, I've got
to conclude that sometimes we

weren't very lucky—the Towson

inconsistencies (e.g. 48% from
the field for a four game stretch
prior to the vital Drexel and
Ursinus games, in which the
group hit at an anemic 29%
clip), the loss of soph John MacKay, and the fact that some
players had poorer seasons than
expected as more obvious factors in Jay difficulties and as
manifestations of the "intangible" problems.

varsity wrestling team, will compete on March 10-11 in the Interstate Intercollegiate Individual Invitational Tournament at
Case Institute in Cleveland, Ohio.
This is the largest invitational
tournament east of the Mississippi and it is the prelude to the
NCAA's, which Hopkins is not
eligible to attend.
Grapplers Need Support
Because of the nature of postseason tournaments, however,
Swartz and two freshmen, Bob
Hyde and Bob Hyams(who will
compete against the Navy plebes
this week-end) must use their
own funds in order to attend
these events.
The Booster Club, in attempting to seek aid for these athletes,
has already received monetary
pledges from various fraternities
and service organizations on
campus.
The Athletic Department provides funds for each sport and
any post-season tournament that
is regularly scheduled, for example, the MAC swimming
championships. However, the
University policy does not include support in entering larger
tournaments like these Nationals.

is well qualified to represent

he has compiled a 16-0-1 record,
and he is the 1966 Mason-Dixon

weight class.

Ghost of Honor
Those members of the Honor Commission who are
against the proposed change in the accused-accuser relationship claim that the integrity for the Honor System is maintained only if everyone in the community is
assured the grade he fairly deserves. The prospect of a
confrontation with the accused party at an honor trial
would, they suggest, deter students from reporting
suspected violations, thus reducing the effectiveness of
the System.
The System is conceived, however, as ideally being, presumably on the basis of principle,
self-enforc
ing
not convenience. The student who fails to report a
suspected violation becomes an accessory to the fact and
is thereby also guilty under the System. That its effectiveness might be impaired would be due not to the proposed change, but a general lack of commitiment on the
part of the students.
Furthermore, according to the statistics revealed at
last Sunday's open forum, an average of only twenty
violations are reported each year, half of which result
in convictions. Although students submit half of the reports of suspected violations, only three of the ten on the
average result in convictions, the other seven having been
initiated on the part of the faculty.
This proportion exists, we are told, because a faculty member usually is in a better poiston to judge if a
violation has taken place. In any case, it should he painfully obvious that an average of twenty reported violations _implies there is a minimal committment to the
System as it stands. Even if a few students are deterred
by the prospect of facing the accused, the Honor System
will hardly he dealt a serious blow.
That there is a greater proportion of convictions
this year to the same number of reported violations is
probably one reason why the issue has been raised at
this time, and all the more reason why the change should
be carried out. The Honor Commission must afford the
accused every possible means to clear himself, and a confrontation with the accuser might clarify questions of
fact wich would otherwise he overlooked.
Opponents of the change also argue that when the
accuser faces the accused, there is an implicit moral
judgment on the accuser's part which is not present
under the current procedure. If we accept, however, the
analogy of the Honor System to the American legal system, we see that it is not really the individual who is
the accuser, but the System through the agency of the
Honor Commission, more specifically the Commission
Counsel, who acts as proseutor. The trial panel serves
in the capacity of judge, while the so-called accuser is
actually a witness, though one who has also fulfilled a
constructive duty under the Honor Code to report a
suspected violation.
Inasmuch as the Honor Commission Constitution
currently employs the terms "accused" and "accuser," a
redefinition of this relationship along the lines stated
above should be undertaken, regardless of the outcome
of the confrontation question. It should be noted in
passing that this redefinition was suggested by a nonCommission member at Sunday's forum, and was perhaps the most significant comment made at the meeting,
an indication in itself of the value of such gatherings.
Judging from the positions taken by Commission
members at the forum, the Commission seems to be
evenly divided over the proposed change. The issue
should ultimately be resolved by a student referendum,
although we hope that the Commission will first make
further efforts to appraise students of the nature and
implications of the proposal in question.

By GERALD BRECHER
The recent controversy over
the C.I.A.'s funding of various
student organizations in this
country is one of the more ridiculous affairs of recent history.
To read such eminent authorities
as the editorial page of the New
York Times, one would imagine
that some diabolical plot had
been hatched by a crew of evil
spies—dressed all in glistening
black, no doubt—and that this
plot would soon have swallowed
up every student in the country
had not Ramparts magazine—of
all people—not exposed this sordid affair.
This sounds like patent nonsense, and probably is. One of
the things that the New York
Times and other journalistic organs don't seem to realize is
that things like the National Student Association aren't terribly
important at all. The influence
of the organized student in this
country doesn't amount to a hill
of beans. The good gray image
of the independent young student, off to seek truth and enlightenment in a democratic
world is a mere illusion in the
United States. The C.I.A. wasn't
perverting anything that was
simon-pure in the first place;
rather it was taking advantage
of a situation long in existence.

make it through the universities
are—almost by definition, the
future leaders of the country.
Their organizations, then, are
important—not only to the students themselves, but necessarily to their countries as well. The
student organizations in the
merging nations are perhaps the
most vocal, if not effective forces
in expressing whatever political
opinion happens to be popular
at the time.

To The Editors:
Of the 1700 students who registered for the second term, only
415 returned the questionnaire
that we distributed during the
registration period.
289 of those who responded
said they were able to enroll in
their first choice courses; 50
were caught in schedule conflicts; 42 were dissatisfied with
matters unrelated to the schedule, such as advising, course sequences or limited enrollments;
and 34 replies could not be used
because of insufficient or incorrect information.
I wish to thank all those who
took the trouble to fill out the
questionnaire.
Comments concerning course
offerings and advising will be
referred to the dean's office;
matters dealing directly with the
schedule are receiving attention
in my office.
Irene M. Davis

Examining produce in an open-air marketplace in Lisbon is one way
to broade
edge of the ways of the Portuguese people. These girls found exploring the market n one's knowls of cities around
the world a relaxing change from studies undertaken during a semester at sea on
Chapman College's
floating campus-now called World Campus Afloat.
Alzada Knickerbocker of Knoxville,Tennessee.-in the plaid dress-r
eturned from the 'studytravel semester to complete her senior year in English at Radcliffe College
.
Jan Knippers of Lawrenceburg. Tennessee. a graduate of the Univers
ity of Tennessee. and a
former Peace Corps Volunteer, first pursued graduate studies in Interna
tional Relations and returned a second semester as a teaching assistant in Spanish on the world
-circling campus.
Students live and attend regular classes aboard the s.s. RYN DAM,
owned by the ECL Shipping
Co. of Bremen for which the Holland-America Line acts as general passeng
er agent. In-port activities arc arranged to supplement courses taught aboard ship.
As you read this, the spring semester voyage of discovery is carryin
g 450 undergraduate and
graduate students through the Panama Canal to call at ports in
Venezuela. Brazil. Argentina. Nigeria,
Senegal, Morocco, Spain, Portugal, The Netherlands, Denmark
and Great Britain, returning to New
York May 25.
Next fall World Campus Afloat-Chapman College will take
another 500 students around the
world from New York to Los Angeles and in the spring, a
new student body will journey from
Los Angeles to ports on both west and east coasts of South
.America, in western and northern
Europe and as far east as Leningrad before returning to New
York.

Quint Completes Year
On Impressive Note

Swartz, Two Frosh
Wrestle In Tourneys

By MIKE PHILLIPS
Displaying flashes of a form,
sadly lacking for much of this
season, the varsity basketball
team, closed a generally disappointing '66-67 campaign with
two impressive wins, thus barely equaling last year's final record.
In destroying Loyola's MasonDixon title hopes for the second straight year and dealing a
94-83 setback to Western Maryland, the cagers fiinished on a
happy note and to some extent
atoned for earlier misfortunes,
but, when compared to pre-season expectations, this year's results—an 8-9 'overall mark, with
a third place, 7-5 log in the Southern Division of the Middle Atlantic Conference and a 3-4 Mason-Dixon mark—will not so easily be explained away.
Though somewhat more accurate (10-7 and about third
place in the M.A.C.) in his assesment of the team's hopes than
pre-season prognosticators like
this writer (13-4 and no worse
than second), varsity coach Henry Ciccarone was hardly overjoyed about the efforts of his
charges, but could not relate
their failures to any specific factor.
Intangibles
"Probably the biggest causes of
our problems were a lot in intangibles," he opined; "I think
the team learned a few things
this year—mostly important that
a winning season just won't happen. Our opponents took us a lot
more seriously, and sometimes
we didn't have the 'little extra'
that was there the year before.
Finally, in thinking of the three
games lost in overtime, I've got
to conclude that sometimes we

weren't very lucky—the Towson
loss in particular was crucial."
Turning to more concrete matters, the varsity mentor rated
his squad's recurrent rebounding difficulties against strong
opposition teams(outdone 52.2 to
52.4 for the year), its occasional
defensive breakdowns, shooting
inconsistencies (e.g. 48% from
the field for a four game stretch
prior to the vital Drexel and
Ursinus games, in which the
group hit at an anemic 29%
clip), the loss of soph John MacKay, and the fact that some
players had poorer seasons than
expected as more obvious factors in Jay difficulties and as
manifestations of the "intangible" problems.

Bill Swartz, co-captain of the
varsity wrestling team, will compete on March 10-11 in the Interstate Intercollegiate Individual Invitational Tournament at
Case Institute in Cleveland, Ohio.
This is the largest invitational
tournament east of the Mississippi and it is the prelude to the
NCAA's, which Hopkins is not
eligible to attend.
Grapplers Need Support
Because of the nature of postseason tournaments, however,
Swartz and two freshmen, Bob
Hyde and Bob Hyams(who will
compete against the Navy plebes
this week-end) must use their
own funds in order to attend
these events.
The Booster Club, in attempting to seek aid for these athletes,
has already received monetary
pledges from various fraternities
and service organizations on
campus.
The Athletic Department provides funds for each sport and
any post-season tournament that
is regularly scheduled, for example, the MAC swimming
championships. However, the
University policy does not include support in entering larger
tournaments like these Nationals.
Swartz M•D Champ
There is no doubt that Swartz
is well qualified to represent
Hopkins. In two varsity seasons
he has compiled a 16-0-1 record,
and he is the 1966 Mason-Dixon
Champion in the 167 pound
weight class.
